item.title: A concise guide to create a web site in 4 steps using Blogdown
item.description:
Get Started:

Putting up your personal web site in the internet is everyone’s dream. There are numerous web site building platforms out there, like Wix or WordPress. Of those tools, WordPress is the most popular. It provides you a suite of service to create a beautiful web site, either blog or e-commence site. Using WordPress, you do not need to know how to code like HTML, CSS, and JavaScript.

However, all those service comes with some of costs despite the cost may be minimal. For example, you need to stay committed financially to buy domain name and pay hosting service provider to host your web site. If you are in the business, you also need to pay for the business email address. If it is the first time for you build site and with purpose of sharing your knowledge, it is not worth doing that way. More importantly, those website building service would hide the coding from you, which is not desirable for programmers.

It had appeared to me that there are quite a few of coding languages you need to master before you can put up a nice web site in the internet. For example, basic languages include HTML, CSS and JavaScript. Regarding the back-end language, you probably need to learn PHP, Java or Python. But it become so easy to create a web site when you use R blogdown . It excludes the need to buy domain name and pay hosting service. With simply 4 steps under 10 minutes, you can make your professional web site available to the world.

Below I am going to use 4 steps to show how to create a skeleton of website using Blogdown in R Studio. assuming you are a programmer and have a knowledge of R.

Software Requirements

Assume you have already installed R (https://www.r-project.org) [@R-base] and the RStudio IDE (https://www.rstudio.com). then do the following:

  1. Install package Blogdown in RStudio IDE
  2. install package Hugo
## Install from CRAN

install.packages('blogdown') 

## Or, install from GitHub

if (!requireNamespace("devtools")) install.packages('devtools')

devtools::install_github('rstudio/blogdown')

blogdown::install_hugo()

Assume that you already have an GitHub account. If you do not have the account, go to the GitHub https://github.com/ and set up your account. It is free. Next, I am going to use 4 steps to show how to put up a skeleton of web site that is beautiful enough for you to deploy to the internet. Based on the skeleton website, you can work on R code (Markdown) to add contents to and modify your site continuously.

Step 1: Create a repository in your GitHub account

Once you have set up your GitHub account, create a new repository.

Step 2: in R studio, create a project using version control

Now working on the local machine.

Create a project from R studio by following this sequence of clicks: File > New Project > Version Control > Git. You will end up with a window below

  • Repository URL: copy the URL site from your repository in the GitHub here.
  • Project Reposition Name: put down directory name you want to call here. This is the working folder that hold your files.
  • Create Project as Subdirectory of: a folder you want to place under.

Once you click Create Project, the repository in your GitHub will be cloned to the folder in local machine. But it is still empty. Next step is to build a web site files using hugo academic theme within the folder just created. Run the R statement below, a static web site will be generated as a result.

# for example, create a new site with the academic theme

blogdown::new_site(theme = "gcushen/hugo-academic", theme_example = TRUE)

Then, go to menu Addins > Serve site. You will see a website is created in the Viewer panel on the right panel.

But this is a template which does not show your name and your blogs. You need to update them based on the temlpate files, YOu change site name, menu, contact information to make it become your web site. Below is a minimal set of files you need to update.

  1. Change biography section and update the Picture: Go to content > author > admin folder and open _index.md file to update your biography including education, email address, organization, and short biography. In the same folder, change the avatar.jpg to your picture
  2. Change the contact information: Go to Config >default folder. Open Params.toml and update the email, contact, phone for yours.
  3. Delete contents. If you do not want to display talks you have given, go to content > home folder, Open file talks.md and edit the yaml header by setting value of Active from True to False. Sections like Publications can be made to disappear in the same way.
  4. remove the Banner above the menu. Go to content > home folder and open file hero.md. Edit toml file heard by resetting the value of Active to False.

With above changes, the web site will have you name, picture, and biography. so, you become the owner of the web site. Now, you can push the contents to your GitHub repository in your GitHub account.

Step 3: Push contents back to your GitHub account

in the RStudio terminal folder, run below statement sequentially.

git add .

git commit -m 'your comment about change'

git push origin master

Step 4: Deploy contents to Netlify

Go to the Netlify https://www.netlify.com/. Since this site allows you to deploy your content directly from GitHub, you do not even need to set up account in Netlify. With the site, you will see the page as below

Make sure that you check the GitHub.

Once your site is deployed, Netlify will assign a random name to your subdomain like random-word-12345.netlify.com. You can change the random text to a more meaningful text. For example, I changed the random text to be my name: dongsuncao so that my site address will be end up being http://dongsuncao.netlify.com.

Then your site is live. You can access the site from anywhere and anytime.

Recap:

The steps I described here are a simplified but working procedure, but it allows you to create and deploy your web site in shortest possible time. For each step, there may be other ways to do it. This is very important when you encounter an issue, You have choices to get around the hurdle. For example, to upload the contents to the GitHub account, you can simply go to Tool > version control >commit. then you add file you want to commit, once it is done, simply use Push button to upload the files to GitHub.

To completely own the site, you need to work on more files. For example, to post a blog, you can click on Addins and click on the new post.

Beyond the basics

If you want to learn more, please read Allison’s blog https://alison.rbind.io/post/up-and-running-with-blogdown/ and documention in GitHub https://github.com/rstudio/blogdown/tree/master/docs

item.title: Shiny Application: Use of Cluster Anlysis to Detect Multiple Enrollments in Clinical Trials
item.description:
Abstract:

Multiple enrollment refers to a practice of a patient taking part in a clinical trial at more than two sites within same study or in multiple studies within same clinical program.

Patients seek multiple enrollments for a variety of reasons. Some seek more access to the study drugs while others are seeking additional compensations. Whatever reasons, multiple enrollments by a single patient at different sites in a study or across studies compromises the data integrity and jeopardizes the patient’s safety.

A web application was developed to facilitate identification of possible multiple participation by same subjects using Shiny platform. In this application, subjects with identical date of birth are identified and their similarity measures are plotted against the birth dates using Plotly. Subjects are clustered based on the similarity measures. The bar graph of similarity measures against birth dates is used to select the subjects with same birth dates and to update the dendrogram to visualize the extent of their similarity with regard to the findings in domains LB, EG, and VS. Concurrently, the pattern of medical history and concomitant medications for selected subjects are compared in the lower panel of the dashboard (Figure 1).

Figre 1. A Dashboard to Show Similarity Measures, Clusters, Medical History, and Conmmitant Medicaitons for Subejcts with Same Birth Dates

From the Figure 1, subjects with same date of birth are identified in the bar graph. Clicking on the bar will select the subject IDs and highlight cluster in the dendrogram allowing for visualization of extent of similarity. The two graphs in the lower panel compare the medical history and concomitant medication before they get enrolled.

item.title: Academic: the website designer for Hugo
item.description:
Academic makes it easy to create a beautiful website for free using Markdown. Customize anything on your site with widgets, themes, and language packs.

Follow our easy step by step guide to learn how to build your own free website with Academic. Check out the personal demo or the business demo of what you’ll get in less than 10 minutes.

  • View the documentation
  • Ask a question
  • Request a feature or report a bug
  • Updating? View the Update Guide and Release Notes
  • Support development of Academic:
    • Donate a coffee
    • Become a backer on Patreon
    • Decorate your laptop or journal with an Academic sticker
    • Wear the T-shirt

Key features:

  • Easily manage various content including homepage, blog posts, publications, talks, and projects
  • Extensible via color themes and widgets/plugins
  • Write in Markdown for easy formatting and code highlighting, with LaTeX for mathematical expressions
  • Social/academic network linking, Google Analytics, and Disqus comments
  • Responsive and mobile friendly
  • Simple and refreshing one page design
  • Multilingual and easy to customize

Color Themes

Academic is available in different color themes and font themes.

Ecosystem

  • Academic Admin: An admin tool to import publications from BibTeX or import assets for an offline site
  • Academic Scripts: Scripts to help migrate content to new versions of Academic

Install

You can choose from one of the following four methods to install:

  • one-click install using your web browser (recommended)
  • install on your computer using Git with the Command Prompt/Terminal app
  • install on your computer by downloading the ZIP files
  • install on your computer with RStudio

Quick install using your web browser

  1. Install Academic with Netlify
    • Netlify will provide you with a customizable URL to access your new site
  2. On GitHub, go to your newly created academic-kickstart repository and edit config.toml to personalize your site. Shortly after saving the file, your site will automatically update
  3. Read the Quick Start Guide to learn how to add Markdown content. For inspiration, refer to the Markdown content which powers the Demo

Install with Git

Prerequisites:

  • Download and install Git
  • Download and install Hugo

  1. Fork the Academic Kickstart repository and clone your fork with Git:

    git clone https://github.com/sourcethemes/academic-kickstart.git My_Website

    Note that if you forked Academic Kickstart, the above command should be edited to clone your fork, i.e. replace sourcethemes with your GitHub username.

  2. Initialize the theme:

    cd My_Website
git submodule update --init --recursive

Install with ZIP

  1. Download and extract Academic Kickstart
  2. Download and extract the Academic theme to the themes/academic/ folder from the above step

Install with RStudio

View the guide to installing Academic with RStudio

Quick start

  1. If you installed on your computer, view your new website by running the following command:

    hugo server

    Now visit localhost:1313 and your new Academic powered website will appear. Otherwise, if using Netlify, they will provide you with your URL.

  2. Read the Quick Start Guide to learn how to add Markdown content, customize your site, and deploy it. For inspiration, refer to the Markdown content which powers the Demo

  3. Build your site by running the hugo command. Then host it for free using Github Pages or Netlify (refer to the first installation method). Alternatively, copy the generated public/ directory (by FTP, Rsync, etc.) to your production web server (such as a university’s hosting service).

Updating

Feel free to star the project on Github to help keep track of updates and check out the release notes prior to updating your site.

Before updating the framework, it is recommended to make a backup of your entire website directory (or at least your themes/academic directory) and record your current version number.

By default, Academic is installed as a Git submodule which can be updated by running the following command:

git submodule update --remote --merge

Check out the update guide for full instructions and alternative methods.

Feedback & Contributing

Please use the issue tracker to let me know about any bugs or feature requests, or alternatively make a pull request.

For support, head over to the Hugo discussion forum.

item.title: Hello R Markdown
item.description:
R Markdown

This is an R Markdown document. Markdown is a simple formatting syntax for authoring HTML, PDF, and MS Word documents. For more details on using R Markdown see http://rmarkdown.rstudio.com.

You can embed an R code chunk like this:

summary(cars)
##      speed           dist       
##  Min.   : 4.0   Min.   :  2.00  
##  1st Qu.:12.0   1st Qu.: 26.00  
##  Median :15.0   Median : 36.00  
##  Mean   :15.4   Mean   : 42.98  
##  3rd Qu.:19.0   3rd Qu.: 56.00  
##  Max.   :25.0   Max.   :120.00
fit <- lm(dist ~ speed, data = cars)
fit
## 
## Call:
## lm(formula = dist ~ speed, data = cars)
## 
## Coefficients:
## (Intercept)        speed  
##     -17.579        3.932

Including Plots

You can also embed plots. See Figure 1 for example:

par(mar = c(0, 1, 0, 1))
pie(
  c(280, 60, 20),
  c('Sky', 'Sunny side of pyramid', 'Shady side of pyramid'),
  col = c('#0292D8', '#F7EA39', '#C4B632'),
  init.angle = -50, border = NA
)

Figure 1: A fancy pie chart.

item.title: Slides
item.description:
Welcome to Slides

Academic

Features

  • Efficiently write slides in Markdown
  • 3-in-1: Create, Present, and Publish your slides
  • Supports speaker notes
  • Mobile friendly slides

Controls

  • Next: Right Arrow or Space
  • Previous: Left Arrow
  • Start: Home
  • Finish: End
  • Overview: Esc
  • Speaker notes: S
  • Fullscreen: F
  • Zoom: Alt + Click
  • PDF Export: E

Code Highlighting

Inline code: variable

Code block:

porridge = "blueberry"
if porridge == "blueberry":
    print("Eating...")

Math

In-line math: $x + y = z$

Block math:

$$ f\left( x \right) = \;\frac{{2\left( {x + 4} \right)\left( {x - 4} \right)}}{{\left( {x + 4} \right)\left( {x + 1} \right)}} $$

Fragments

Make content appear incrementally

{{% fragment %}} One {{% /fragment %}}
{{% fragment %}} **Two** {{% /fragment %}}
{{% fragment %}} Three {{% /fragment %}}

Press Space to play!

One Two Three

A fragment can accept two optional parameters:

  • class: use a custom style (requires definition in custom CSS)
  • weight: sets the order in which a fragment appears

Speaker Notes

Add speaker notes to your presentation

{{% speaker_note %}}
- Only the speaker can read these notes
- Press `S` key to view
{{% /speaker_note %}}

Press the S key to view the speaker notes!

  • Only the speaker can read these notes
  • Press S key to view

Themes

  • black: Black background, white text, blue links (default)
  • white: White background, black text, blue links
  • league: Gray background, white text, blue links
  • beige: Beige background, dark text, brown links
  • sky: Blue background, thin dark text, blue links
  • night: Black background, thick white text, orange links
  • serif: Cappuccino background, gray text, brown links
  • simple: White background, black text, blue links
  • solarized: Cream-colored background, dark green text, blue links

Custom Slide

Customize the slide style and background

{{< slide background-image="/img/boards.jpg" >}}
{{< slide background-color="#0000FF" >}}
{{< slide class="my-style" >}}

Custom CSS Example

Let’s make headers navy colored.

Create assets/css/reveal_custom.css with:

.reveal section h1,
.reveal section h2,
.reveal section h3 {
  color: navy;
}

Questions?

Ask
